content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame
  SpriteSet
    floor > Immovable randomtiling=0.9 img=oryx/floor3 hidden=True
    goal  > Door color=GREEN img=oryx/doorclosed1
    key   > Immovable color=ORANGE img=oryx/key2
    sword > OrientedFlicker limit=5 singleton=True img=oryx/slash1
    movable >
      avatar  > ShootAvatar   stype=sword frameRate=8
        nokey   > img=oryx/swordman1
        withkey > color=ORANGE img=oryx/swordmankey1
      enemy >  
        monsterQuick > RandomNPC cooldown=2 cons=6 img=oryx/bat1
        monsterNormal > RandomNPC cooldown=4 cons=8 img=oryx/spider2
        monsterSlow > RandomNPC cooldown=8 cons=12 img=oryx/scorpion1
      wall > Immovable autotiling=true img=oryx/wall3
      	

  LevelMapping
    g > floor goal
    + > floor key        
    A > floor nokey
    1 > floor monsterQuick
    2 > floor monsterNormal
    3 > floor monsterSlow
    w > wall
    . > floor
    

  InteractionSet
    movable wall  > stepBack
    nokey goal    > stepBack
    goal withkey  > killSprite scoreChange=1
    enemy sword > killSprite scoreChange=2
    enemy enemy > stepBack
    avatar enemy > killSprite scoreChange=-1
    nokey key     > transformTo stype=withkey scoreChange=1 killSecond=True

  TerminationSet
    SpriteCounter stype=goal   win=True
    SpriteCounter stype=avatar win=False
This is vgdl rule in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐language breakdown of what you’re looking at:

1. Game Type and Overall Goal
 • It’s a maze‐ or puzzle–style game played on a grid, where you control an avatar that can both shoot a short‐lived “sword” projectile and move around the level.
 • The primary objective is to navigate the level, pick up a key, and then reach the door (the “goal”). Only after you’ve collected the key (which changes your avatar’s state) can you exit safely through the door.
 • A secondary element is dealing with roaming enemies—there are several types that move randomly with differing speeds.

2. Key Mechanics and Rules
 • Movement and Environment:
  – The level is laid out like a maze with walls (immovable obstacles) that you can’t pass through.
  – The floor is a background sprite that isn’t directly visible.
 • The Key and Transformations:
  – You start as a “nokey” avatar.
  – When you come into contact with the key sprite, you transform into a “withkey” state (and gain a bit of score). This transformation is essential because without the key your avatar is blocked from interacting with the door.
 • The Door (Goal):
  – If you are “withkey” and you reach the door (goal sprite), an interaction triggers that removes the door and adds to your score, signalling level completion (win condition).
 • Combat and Enemies:
  – Your avatar is equipped with a sword that “flickers” briefly (only up to 5 uses at a time, and only one exists at a time). You can shoot this sword to kill enemies.
  – If the sword hits an enemy, that enemy is removed and you earn extra points.
  – However, if you come into direct contact with an enemy (without using your sword), the enemy is still removed but you lose points.
  – Different types of monsters (fast, normal, slow) wander the level randomly, so they’re both obstacles and potential targets.
 • Other Details:
  – There are clear collision rules: for example, your “nokey” avatar is blocked from going through the goal until it picks up the key, and “movable” sprites bounce off walls.

3. Win/Loss Conditions
 • Win: You win if you successfully use your “withkey” status to trigger the door (goal), completing the level.
 • Loss: You lose if your avatar is eliminated (for example, if an enemy touches you without proper caution, resulting in your removal).

4. Strategy Tips
 • First, focus on reaching the key. Since you start as “nokey,” you must grab the key (found somewhere in the maze) to change your state. Plan your route to avoid open encounters with the roaming monsters.
 • Use the environment (the walls and maze structure) to your advantage. They can help you block enemy paths and provide cover as you approach the key.
 • Keep your sword ready: shoot it to eliminate dangerous enemies from a distance. Use projectile attacks rather than direct contact to avoid the point loss penalty.
 • After obtaining the key, plot a careful path to the door. Passing through the maze might require timing your movements to dodge the enemies’ random motions.
 • Monitor the different enemy speeds. The faster “monsterQuick” might require sudden changes in direction, while the slower ones may be easier to plan around.
 • Overall, balance caution with aggression—engage enemies smartly using your sword, but avoid unnecessary encounters that could drain your score and risk your avatar’s survival.

This strategy should help you plan your moves: get the key safely, use your sword to thin out threats, and steadily make your way to the door for a win.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game.

Action:5

I'm moving up from (7,1) to (6,1) to avoid interfering with my sword's current flickering path, expecting that the sword will continue moving right and eventually collide with the enemy at (7,4) for a clean kill.

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
floor goal -> 'g'
floor key -> '+'
floor nokey -> 'A'
floor monsterQuick -> '1'
floor monsterNormal -> '2'
floor monsterSlow -> '3'
wall -> 'w'
floor -> '.'
goal -> '@'
key -> '#'
monsterNormal -> '$'
monsterQuick -> '%'
monsterSlow -> '&'
nokey -> '*'
sword -> 'k'
withkey -> 'm'
